metadata.title: Cyber-attack localisation and tolerant control for microgrid energy management system based on set-membership estimation
metadata.abstract: This paper addresses the cyber-security issue of microgrid energy management system, where cyber-attacks, appearing in communication networks, corrupt the transmitted data and falsify the state estimates. This can potentially threaten the physical system and lead to severe physical consequences. Therefore, it is of great significance to detect, locate and tolerate cyber-attacks. To this end, set-membership estimation is employed to detect the occurrence and locate the position of DoS attacks. The model predictive control technique is utilised to schedule the energy management by using the forecasts of photovoltaic generation and load demand. It is shown that the cyber-attack localisation and the desired tolerant control performance against attacks can be both achieved. Simulation results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy.

grobid.contents:
Cyber-attack localisation and tolerant control for microgrid energy management system based on set-membership estimation


Quanwei Qiu 
School of Engineering and Built Environment
Griffith University
Gold CoastAustralia

Fuwen Yang 
School of Engineering and Built Environment
Griffith University
Gold CoastAustralia

Yong Zhu 
School of Engineering and Built Environment
Griffith University
Gold CoastAustralia

Cyber-attack localisation and tolerant control for microgrid energy management system based on set-membership estimation

INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF SYSTEMS SCIENCE
2021610.1080/00207721.2021.1896051Received 28 October 2020 Accepted 22 February 2021Energy management systemcyber securitymulti-microgrid systemmodel predictive controlset-membership estimation
This paper addresses the cyber-security issue of microgrid energy management system, where cyberattacks, appearing in communication networks, corrupt the transmitted data and falsify the state estimates. This can potentially threaten the physical system and lead to severe physical consequences. Therefore, it is of great significance to detect, locate and tolerate cyber-attacks. To this end, set-membership estimation is employed to detect the occurrence and locate the position of DoS attacks. The model predictive control technique is utilised to schedule the energy management by using the forecasts of photovoltaic generation and load demand. It is shown that the cyber-attack localisation and the desired tolerant control performance against attacks can be both achieved. Simulation results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy.ARTICLE HISTORY

Introduction

An increasing number of renewable energy sources (RESs), such as solar panels and wind turbines, are being integrated into power grids for environmental, economical, and technical reasons Olivares et al., 2014). To manage the distributed energy resources, storage devices, and loads efficiently, microgrid technology was proposed by Lasseter (2001) and has been widely studied and used. Unlike traditional synchronous generators, RESs need to use the power electronic converters as an interface with the power grid, which causes low inertia for microgrids. Moreover, the fluctuating power output of a RES may affect the operation of microgrids. This requires safe and efficient measures to smooth the output fluctuation and thus provide a reliable power system. To handle these problems, energy storages such as batteries are usually adopted to store and supply energy to diminish power fluctuation and enhance inertia. It is therefore of great importance to design some control strategy for an energy management system (EMS) to coordinate the charging and discharging schedule of battery storage units such that power in microgrids can be properly regulated to fulfil all load requirements. To efficiently coordinate EMSs for microgrids, some communication network is often necessary for performing data transmission among distributed sensors, controllers and actuators, given that RESs are usually geographically dispersed (Ouammi et al., 2015;Yan et al., 2019). From this perspective, a microgrid that incorporates smart metering, communication and computing elements into the conventional electricity infrastructure represents a typical cyber-physical system (Ding et al., 2019;Faza et al., 2010). The addition of these elements can enhance stability and reliability of microgrids, which, however, also induces cyber security issues because communication networks are often open and vulnerable to adversarial attacks. From a control perspective, three typical types of cyberattacks, that is, denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, reply attacks, and deception attacks have been extensively studied in the literature (Ding et al., 2018), see also the recent survey (Gao et al., 2020;Song et al., 2020;.

A successful attack against the sensing and communication system of a microgrid may threaten power system operation, which may further result in instability, faults or even failures of a microgrid. Therefore, detection, localisation and tolerance of cyber-attacks are essential for security and reliability of microgrids. In the literature, researchers have proposed different cyber-attack detection methods for power systems, such as robust principal component analysis algorithm (Mahapatra & Chaudhuri, 2019), generalised cumulative sum algorithm (Kurt et al., 2018), residue-based observes/estimators (Ge et al., 2019), graph signal processing (Drayer & Routtenberg, 2018;Ramakrishna & Scaglione, 2019) and so on. Moreover, cyber-attack localisation is especially critical for those large-scale systems that consist of multiple subsystems such as multi-microgrid systems (MMSs). In Abul Hasnat and Rahnamay-Naeini (2019), a method was proposed to detect and locate both cyber and physical attacks in smart grids by exploiting the correlation among the states of the components. In Drayer and Routtenberg (2019), a cyber-attack localisation method was presented for smart grids using graph modulation.

State estimation is critical for realising accurate control of a microgrid as it processes the measurement data and calculates the state of every bus Liang et al., 2017). Attacks against communication networks, via corrupting the transmissions of system data, can significantly affect the state estimation process and subsequently lead to dysfunctions of EMS. Different state estimation approaches, for example, Kalman filtering and H ∞ filtering, have been used in the literature (Ding et al., 2019;Kurt et al., 2018;H. Zhang et al., 2014). Yet, these estimation approaches are essentially pointwise, meaning that the computed state estimates are single vectors. Besides, the celebrated Kalman filtering necessitates the specific statistical properties of disturbances/noises and the H ∞ filtering requires the accumulated energy of the disturbances/noises during the estimation procedures. To overcome these limitations, an alternative set-membership estimation (SME) or set-membership filtering, which calculates a bounding ellipsoidal set that encloses all possible state estimations with the assumption that the noises are unknown-but-bounded, has been extensively investigated in many works (Qiu et al., 2020;Yang & Li, 2009a, 2009bZhao et al., 2020). The SME method has also been applied to solve different cyber-attack or fault detection problems in the literature. For example, Mousavinejad et al. (2018) proposed a two-step cyber-attack detection method for networked control systems; they further developed this method into distributed cases and applied it in a vehicle platooning control system in another paper (Ju et al., 2020b;Mousavinejad et al., 2020) proposed a distributed method based on SME to solve the fault detection problem over sensor networks with the presence of the weighted try-once-discard (WTOD) protocol. However, most existing SME schemes can only distinguish whether there exists a cyber-attack, but cannot indicate where the cyber-attack occurs accurately.

Apart from attack detection and localisation, another essential task is to develop some effective measures to overcome cyber-attacks, that is, cyberattack tolerant control (Sathishkumar & Liu, 2020). To deal with communication failures caused by cyberattacks in RES-based microgrids, a promising method is model predictive control (MPC). This is because an MPC technique has the advantage of employing forecasts conveniently, which is significant in terms of addressing the intermittency of RES generation. By using the forecasts of RES generation and load demand, MPC predicts a sequence of control inputs that can optimally regulate energy management for microgrids (Brenna et al., 2018). In addition, the control sequence can be used as default set-point power values for RESs and batteries. This enables the electrical devices to overcome communication failures by implementing the precomputed default values when a new control signal update is unavailable due to cyberattack.

Inspired by these factors above, the objective of this paper is to design a cyber-attack detection and localisation method and a cyber-attack tolerant controller for a microgrid EMS. In this design, the communication network of the EMS, through which system data are transmitted, is threatened by DoS attacks. SME is used to estimate the battery states affected by unknown-but-bounded process disturbance and measurement noise. Based on the calculated ellipsoidal estimates, the cyber-attack can be detected and located through a localisation criterion. MPC controller is communication-based and designed in a centralised way. It optimises the control sequence for the EMS and provides real-time set-point control signals for local units. In summary, the main contributions of this paper are twofold and highlighted as follows:

(1) A cyber-attack localisation method is designed to locate the DoS attack using set-membership estimation; (2) An MPC controller is designed to achieve the cyber-attack tolerant control for the EMS of RES-based microgrids.

The remainder of this paper is organised as follows. Section 2 models the investigated system. Based on this model, Section 3 derives the ellipsoidal state estimation method and gives the cyber-attack localisation criterion, and Section 4 introduces the MPC controller design. Section 5 presents the recursive cyber-attack localisation and tolerant control algorithm. Section 6 shows the simulation test results, and Section 7 concludes the paper.


System modelling


System description

This paper considers an MMS that is completely supplied by photovoltaic (PV) generators as illustrated in Figure 1. Each PV generator is equipped with a battery to store the excess generated power and provide power to the load when required. A centralised energy management controller coordinates the charging and discharging schedule of the battery storages. It can communicate with the smart meters installed at local units wirelessly to collect energy use data and transmit set-point control signals. The solid lines in Figure  1 represent the electricity transmission lines, while the dashed lines represent the communication network. 


Dynamic model of battery storages

In the MMS, there are n b ∈ Z + battery storage units. The discrete-time model for the battery of the ith subsystem is given by the following:
x i,k+1 = x i,k − T s u b,i,k ,( 1 )
where i ∈ {1, . . . , n b }, x i,k is the absolute state of charge (SoC) of the ith battery at time step k, k ∈ N, u b,i,k is the charging/discharging power of the ith battery at time step k, and T s denotes the sampling time in hours (h). Note that the target system is expressed in a perunit system, which means some elements in the system are represented by per-unit values. Thus, the power quantities are labelled with the symbol pu, while the absolute SoC is labelled with the symbol puh. Thus, the global system model can be described as follows:

⎡
⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ x 1,k+1 x 2,k+1 . . . x n g ,k+1 ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ = ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ x 1,k x 2,k . . . x n g ,k ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ − T s ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ u b,1,k u b,2,k . . . u b,n g ,k ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ .(2)
Further, model (2) can be rewritten into a compact form as follows:
x k+1 = x k − T s u b,k ,( 3 )
where x k ∈ R n b , u b,k ∈ R n b .


Cyber-attack models

DoS attack is considered in the communication channels between the central controller and the local units. In the following, the models of the DoS attacks on both sensor measurement and control signal are given.


Sensor measurement under attack

To describe the sensor measurement under DoS attack, the model used in the reference (Mousavinejad et al., 2018) is adopted here.
y k = y k + y k y a k ,( 4 )
where y a k denotes the attack signal, and it is defined as y a k = −y k to represent the DoS attack. y k ∈ R n b ×n b is a diagonal matrix, which represents the physical constraints imposed on the attack signals in the following form: 


Control signal under attack

Similar as above, the control signal affected by DoS attack can be modelled as
u k = u k + u k u a k ,( 5 )
and u k is expressed as follows:
u k = diag{ξ u 1,k , ξ u 2,k , . . . , ξ u n b ,k }, ξ u l,k ≤ ξ u l,k ≤ ξ u l,k , l = 1, 2, . . . , n b , where ξ u l,k , ξ u l,k ∈ [0, 1].

Attack localisation with ellipsoidal set-Membership estimation

In this section, an SME method is designed to estimate the battery states while also taking into account process disturbances and measurement noises. The system model (3) in Section 2.2 is an ideal model based on the assumption that the system state can be obtained accurately all the time. However, in a practical situation, the system state can be inaccurate or even unavailable. This is especially likely when the system is influenced by process disturbance and measurement noise, and communication failure occurs. To describe the system more precisely, the following disturbed system model is considered:
x k+1 = x k − T s (u b,k + ω k ),y k = x k + υ k ,(6)
where ω k ∈ R n b represents the process disturbance that affects the battery state, which can be caused by the charge/discharge dissipation or power loss of the battery, and υ k ∈ R n b represents the measurement noise that affects the accuracy of the measurement output.

In practice, disturbances are often bounded in some specific ranges. Therefore, the following Assumption 3.1 is given to define the boundary of the disturbances. Assumption 3.2 defines the boundary of the initial system state, which is essential for the recursive state estimation method.

Assumption 3.1: ω k and υ k are unknown but bounded by the following two ellipsoids:
ω k ∈ ε(0, Q k ) = {ω k |ω T k Q −1 k ω k ≤ 1} W k , (7) υ k ∈ ε(0, R k ) = {υ k |υ T k R −1 k υ k ≤ 1} V k ,(8)
where Q k = Q T k > 0 and R k = R T k > 0 are known matrices with compatible dimensions. Q k and R k determine how far the ellipsoids extend in every direction from the origin.


Assumption 3.2:

The initial state is bounded by a given ellipsoid
x 0 ∈ ε(x 0 , P 0 ) = {x 0 |(x 0 −x 0 ) T P −1 0 (x 0 −x 0 ) ≤ 1} X 0 ,( 9 )
wherex 0 is an estimation of x 0 assumed to be given, and P 0 = P T 0 > 0 is a known matrix.


Two-step set-membership estimation method

In the following, the system state is estimated through a prediction step and a measurement update step.


Prediction step

In the prediction step, the known state estimate and control input of the last step are used to predict the current state estimate as follows:
x k|k−1 = A p k−1x k−1 − T s u b,k−1 , y k|k−1 =x k|k−1 ,(10)
where A p k−1 is a parameter matrix to be determined. Provided that the state of the last step resides in an ellipsoid, that is,
x k−1 ∈ ε(x k−1 , P k−1 ), it implies that (x k−1 −x k−1 ) T P −1 k−1 (x k−1 −x k−1 ) ≤ 1. Thus, it can be obtained that there exists a z k−1 with z k−1 ≤ 1 such that x k−1 =x k−1 + E k−1 z k−1 ,(11)
where E k−1 is the Cholesky factorisation of P k−1 , that is, P k−1 = E k−1 E T k−1 . The state prediction error can be obtained as follows:
x k −x k|k−1 = x k−1 − T s u b,k−1 − T s ω k−1 − (A p k−1x k−1|k−1 − T s u b,k−1 ) = x k−1 − A p k−1x k−1|k−1 − T s ω k−1 . (12)
By substituting (11) into (12), the prediction error is updated as follows:
x k −x k|k−1 = (I − A p k−1 )x k−1 + E k−1 z k−1 − T s ω k−1 . (13) Denote that η p k−1 = ⎡ ⎣ 1 z k−1 ω k−1 ⎤ ⎦ ,(14)
then Equation (13) can be rewritten into
x k −x k|k−1 = p k−1 η p k−1 ,(15)where p k−1 = [(I − A p k−1 )x k−1 E k−1 − T s ].
Considering the objective of this prediction step is to find an ellipsoid ε(x k|k−1 , P k|k−1 ) that contains the actual state of the current step x k , the following condition should be satisfied:
(x k −x k|k−1 ) T P −1 k|k−1 (x k −x k|k−1 ) ≤ 1.(16)
By substituting (15) into (16), the inequality can be rewritten as
η p k−1 T ( p k−1 T P −1 k|k−1 p k−1 − diag(1, 0, 0))η p k−1 ≤ 0.(17)
Since the unknown variables z k−1 , ω k−1 within η p k−1 satisfy the following conditions:
z k−1 ≤ 1, ω T k−1 Q −1 k−1 ω k−1 ≤ 1, which can be also expressed with η p k−1 as η p k−1 T diag(−1, I, 0)η p k−1 ≤ 0, η p k−1 T diag(−1, 0, Q −1 k−1 )η p k−1 ≤ 0.(18)
By using S-procedure to (17) and (18) 
η p k−1 T [ p k−1 T P −1 k|k−1 p k−1 − diag(1, 0, 0) − λ p 1 diag (−1, I, 0) − λ p 2 diag(−1, 0, Q −1 k−1 )]η p k−1 ≤ 0. (19) By denoting p k−1 = diag(1 − λ p 1 − λ p 2 , λ p 1 I, λ p 2 Q −1 k−1 ),
inequality (19) can be rewritten as
η p k−1 T ( p k−1 T P −1 k|k−1 p k−1 − p k−1 )η p k−1 ≤ 0. (20)
Through applying Schur complements, inequality (20) is equivalent to the following linear inequality matrix (LMI):
− p k−1 p k−1 T p k−1 −P k|k−1 ≤ 0.(21)
Inequality (21) provides a sufficient condition to obtain the state estimation ellipsoids recursively. To minimise the volumes of the ellipsoids, a convex optimisation approach is derived to find the minimal ellipsoids -that is, P k|k−1 and A p k−1 are obtained by solving the following optimisation problem:
min P k|k−1 ,A p k−1 ,λ p 1 ,λ p 2 traceP k|k−1 , subject to (21).(22)
Thereafter, the current state estimatex k|k−1 can be calculated using (10) and A p k−1 obtained from solving (22). Further, the prediction ellipsoid ε(x k|k−1 , P k|k−1 ) is achieved.


Measurement update step

In the measurement update step, the state estimate of the current time step calculated in the prediction step and the output measurement of the current time step are used to update the current state estimate as follows:
x k =x k|k−1 + L k (y k −ŷ k|k−1 ), y k|k−1 =x k|k−1 .(23)
According to the minimal ellipsoid ε(x k|k−1 , P k|k−1 ) calculated in the prediction step, it can be obtained that there exists a z k|k−1 with z k|k−1 ≤ 1 such that
x k =x k|k−1 + E k|k−1 z k|k−1 ,(24)
where E k|k−1 is the Cholesky factorisation of the shape matrix P k|k−1 . The updated state estimation error can be calculated as follows:
x k −x k =x k|k−1 + E k|k−1 z k|k−1 − (x k|k−1 + L k (y k −ŷ k|k−1 )) = (I − L k )E k|k−1 z k|k−1 − L k υ k .(25)
By denoting
η u k = ⎡ ⎣ 1 z k|k−1 υ k ⎤ ⎦ ,(26)
the state estimation error can be rewritten as
x k −x k = u k η u k ,(27)where u k = [0 (I − L k )E k|k−1 − L k ].
Considering the objective of the measurement update step is to find an ellipsoid ε(x k , P k ) that contains the actual state of the current step, the following condition should be satisfied:
(x k −x k ) T P −1 k (x k −x k ) ≤ 1.(28)
By substituting (27) into (28), the inequality can be rewritten as
η u k T ( u k T P −1 k u k ) − diag(1, 0, 0)η u k ≤ 0.(29)
Since the unknown variables z k|k−1 , υ k within η u k satisfy the following conditions:
z k|k−1 ≤ 1, υ T k R −1 k υ k ≤ 1,
which can be also expressed with η u k as
η u k T diag(−1, I, 0)η u k ≤ 0, η u k T diag(−1, 0, R −1 k )η u k ≤ 0.(30)
By using S-procedure to (29) and (30), it can be obtained that the inequality (29) can hold if there exist nonnegative scalars λ u 1 and λ u 2 such that
η u k T [ u k T P −1 k u k − diag(1, 0, 0) − λ u 1 diag(−1, I, 0) − λ u 2 diag(−1, 0, R −1 k )]η u k ≤ 0.(31)
By denoting
u k = diag(1 − λ u 1 − λ u 2 , λ u 1 I, λ u 2 R −1 k ),
inequality (31) can be rewritten as
η u k T ( u k T P −1 k u k − u k )η u k ≤ 0.(32)
This inequality is also equivalent to the following LMI by using Schur complements:
− u 1 u k T u k −P k ≤ 0.(33)
Similar as in Section 3.1.1, the following optimisation problem is given to minimise the volumes of the updated ellipsoids min P k ,L k ,λ u 1 ,λ u 2 trace P k , subject to (33).

Thereafter, the state estimate of the current step x k can be updated through substituting the calculated x k|k−1 and L k into (23). Then, the updated ellipsoid ε(x k , P k ) is obtained.

Remark 3.1: The disturbance's and noise's effect on the filtering dynamics can be analysed from three aspects: (1) from Inequality (19) and Optimisation Problem (22), it can be observed that the process disturbance ω k−1 is related to the parameter matrix A p k−1 and the shape matrix P k|k−1 of the prediction ellipsoid, which means it will affect the location and shape of the prediction ellipsoid; (2) from Inequality (31) and Optimisation Problem (34), it can be observed that the measurement noise υ k is related to the filter gain matrix L k and the shape matrix P k of the update ellipsoid, which means it will affect the location and shape of the update ellipsoid; (3) the centre of the update ellipsoidx k is calculated using the state estimatex k|k−1 obtained from the prediction step and the prediction shape matrix P k|k−1 is used in the optimisation problem for the update ellipsoid as shown in the expression of u k . These indicate that the process disturbance ω k−1 also has some indirect effects on the location and shape of the update ellipsoid.


Cyber-attack localisation criterion

Based on the two-step estimation strategy noted above, two ellipsoids -prediction ellipsoid and updated ellipsoid are obtained. Then, the following work is to diagnose and locate the cyber-attack, that is, dividing the whole procedure into two steps: determining whether there is cyber-attack and locating the cyber-attack.

In the attack diagnosis stage, a similar method as in the reference (Mousavinejad et al., 2018) is adopted, that is, determining the occurrence of cyber-attack according to the intersection of the prediction ellipsoid ε(x k|k−1 , P k|k−1 ) and the updated ellipsoid ε(x k , P k ). In order to locate the cyber-attack, the information contained in these two ellipsoids can be further utilised. The bounding box aligned with the axes of the coordinate system is adopted here. This kind of bounding box is usually referred to as axis-aligned bounding box (AABB). From the AABBs of the ellipsoids calculated in the attack diagnosis, the boundary limits of the prediction and updated ellipsoids are obtained as {x
p,min i,k , x p,max i,k } and {x u,min i,k , x u,max i,k
}, respectively. Then, the boundary sets can be described as follows:
χ p i,k = {x p i,k |x p,min i,k ≤ x p i,k ≤ x p,max i,k , i ∈ {1, . . . , n b }}, χ u i,k = {x u i,k |x u,min i,k ≤ x u i,k ≤ x u,max i,k , i ∈ {1, . . . , n b }}.
As illustrated in Figure 2, the location of cyberattacks can be identified by comparing the obtained boundary sets. If χ p i,k and χ u i,k have intersections, then there is a cyber-attack occurring at the ith battery, that is,
If χ p i,k ∩ χ u i,k = ∅, there is a attack at ith battery; If χ p i,k ∩ χ u i,k = ∅, there is no attack.(35)
With this attack localisation criterion above, the cyberattack occurring at the MMS can be located accurately through comparing the boundary sets for all dimensions i = 1, . . . , n b .


Remark 3.2:

Although only two battery units are considered in Figure 2, where 2-D ellipses are shown, the proposed detection criterion can work for systems with more battery units. To achieve this, the calculated high dimensional ellipsoids (hyper-ellipsoids) should be projected onto 2-D coordinate planes and the obtained projection will be ellipses, which can be visualised as in the illustration figure above.


Remark 3.3:

If a cyber-attack is too small to separate the two ellipsoids, it cannot be detected as there is still an intersection between the ellipsoids. Therefore, the minimum detectable attack is the attack value that can result in the minimum deviation to the update ellipsoid, subject to the condition that the two ellipsoids have no intersection.


Remark 3.4:

There might exist a special case that the two ellipsoids have no intersection, but the boundary sets in all dimensions still have intersections. This is because the cyber-attack is larger than the minimum detectable attack, but still too small to be accurately located. Therefore, the minimum locatable attack is the attack value that can result in the minimum deviation to the update boundary set, subject to the condition that the two boundary sets of the corresponding dimension have no intersection.


MPC controller design

Since the system model is constructed and cyberattack is located, the next step is to calculate the optimal control sequence as inputs for the controlled system utilising MPC technique. Hence, in this section, the MPC design to realise the cyber-attack tolerant control will be introduced. Constraints will be given to restrain the signals of different system components, cost functions will be designed to emphasise the control objectives by penalising different terms, and the optimisation problem for MPC will be derived. Besides, the update of the default control sequence will be formulated taking into account DoS attacks on actuator networks.


MPC


Component constraints

For the MPC formulation, the following constraints are imposed on battery components:
u min b ≤ u b,k+n|k ≤ u max b , x min ≤ x k+n|k ≤ x max , k, n ≥ 0,(36)
where u min b and u max b denote the operation power limits of batteries, x min and x max are the charge limits.

In addition, a power balance equation must be satisfied.
1 T u s,k+n|k + 1 T u b,k+n|k + 1 T u g,k+n|k + 1 T u l,k+n|k = 0,(37)
where u s,k+n|k is the solar PV generation power, u g,k+n|k is the power supplied to/by the utility grid, and u l,k+n|k is the load demand, 1 is a column vector with appropriate dimension and all elements being 1. If the MMS is islanded -that is, the utility grid power u g,k+n|k = 0 -define u r,k+n|k ∈ R by u r,k+n|k = 1 T u s,k+n|k + 1 T u l,k+n|k , then Equation (37) can be rewritten in the following form:
1 T −1 T u b,k+n|k ≤ −u r,k+n|k u r,k+n|k .(38)

Cost functions

Different cost functions for the grid components are adopted to penalise different control objectives. For batteries, the following cost function is used to reduce high power operation and make the energy levels stay at a threshold:
J b,k+n|k = u T b,k+n|k diag(C b,1 )u b,k+n|k + x T k+n|k diag(C b,2 ) x k+n|k ,(39a)
where
x k+n|k = max(x min b − x k+n|k , 0) + max (x k+n|k − x max b , 0)
. Note that the second term on the right-hand side of Equation (39a) is a soft constraint.

For the grid power, the following cost function is given to make the local microgrids rely less on the utility grid -that is, to reduce the power drawn from or fed into the utility grid:
J g,k+n|k = u T g,k+n|k diag(C g )u g,k+n|k ,(39b)
where u g,k+n|k is the utility grid power to be determined. By summing up all these costs, the overall cost function is obtained as follows:
J k+n|k = J b,k+n|k + J g,k+n|k .
(40)


Optimisation problem

With the constraints and cost functions defined as above, the MPC optimisation problem can be achieved as follows:
min u b ,u g J N k , subject to (6), (36), (38)(42)
where J N k = N−1 n=0 J k+n|k is the sum of the overall cost function J k+n|k over the future control horizon N ∈ N.

Through solving the optimisation problem above, the optimal control sequence can be obtained. In this way, the predicted control inputs for future steps can be utilised as default control sequence and implemented in the unit where cyber-attack occurs and the communication channel is jammed as presented in Section 4.2.


Control sequence update

As illustrated in the top subfigure of Figure 3, assuming that the actuator network of every local unit is free of attack, which means the communication between local units and the central controller at time k are normal, every local unit can receive a control sequence from the controller. At the next time step, k + 1, if the control signal is affected by DoS attack, the local unit will implement the control sequence obtained from the last step k as the default control, which is shown in the second picture; if there is no communication problem, then the local unit will receive a new control sequence from the central controller and update its future default control inputs, as depicted in the bottom subfigure.

With this updated setup, the future default control sequence determined at time step k can be formulated as follows:
u d b,i,k+n|k = u b,i,k+n|k−t , n ∈ Z [0,N−t] , u b,i,k−t+N|k−t , n ∈ Z [N−t+1,N],(42)
where k−t is the last time step before the attack occurs, and u b,i,k−t+n|k−t , n ∈ Z [0,N] is the control sequence computed by solving the MPC optimisation problem (52) at time step k−t.

To overcome the DoS attack on the control signal, the actually implemented control input at every time step is modelled as follows: where A b,k ∈ R n b ×n b is a diagonal matrix, which represents the status of the communication channels in the following form:
u * b,k = A b,k u b,k + (I − A b,k )u d k ,(43)A b,k = diag{a 1,k , a 2,k , . . . , a n b ,k }, a l,k ∈ {0, 1}, l ∈ {1, 2, . . . , n b }.
The value of a l,k are determined by the attack detection result, that is, a l,k = 0 if there is no attack; a l,k = 1 if attack occurs. u d k is the default control input which is pre-defined.


Guaranteed stability analysis

The idea behind the guaranteed stability for a nominal system without disturbances is to impose a terminal state constraint X f on the MPC with a finite horizon N, that is, the MPC is required to steer the state into X f in N steps and then a local stabilising controller K(x k ) can steer any state inside X f to the origin. When introducing the terminal constraint to the disturbed systems, the local stabilising controller K(x k ) needs to ensure that the states always stay inside X f , and X f will be a robust positive invariant set which contains the origin. Hence, in order to achieve the guaranteed stability, X f and K(x k ) should be chosen to satisfy the following conditions:
(1) 0 ∈ X f ; (2) x k − T s K(x k ) − T s ω k ∈ X f , ∀x k ∈ X f . (44)
Assume that the local stabilising controller is a linear feedback controller, that is, K(x k ) = Kx k . Then, the system state evolution of model (6) can be written as
x k+1 = (I − T s K)x k − T s ω k .(45)
To obtain the robust positive invariant set that satisfies the conditions in (44), it is assumed that the process disturbance ω k is bounded by ε(0, Q) and X f is defined by an ellipsoid ε(0, P f ), which is subject to the following implication:
x T k+1 P −1 f x k+1 ≤ 1,(46)when x T k P −1 f x k ≤ 1, ω T k Q −1 ω k ≤ 1.(47)
By using the S-procedure and Schur complement, it can be obtained that the above implication holds if there exist non-negative scalars λ
f 1 and λ f 2 such that ⎡ ⎢ ⎣ −λ f 1 P f * * 0 −λ f 2 Q −1 * P f − T s Y f −T s −P f ⎤ ⎥ ⎦ ≤ 0,(48)λ f 1 + λ f 2 ≤ 1,(49)
where Y f = KP f . To obtain the maximum volume of the robust positive invariant ellipsoid, the following maximisation problem is developed: (48), (49), and λ f 1 ≥ 0, λ f 2 ≥ 0.
max Y f ,P f ,λ f 1 ,λ f 2 trace P f subjectto (36),
(50) By solving this maximisation problem (50), the robust positive invariant ellipsoid can be obtained and incorporated into the MPC optimisation problem (41) by adding the following terminal state constraint:
x T k+N P −1 f x k+N ≤ 1.(51)
Consequently, the MPC optimisation problem can be rewritten into 

Thus, the guaranteed stability of the system under the designed MPC controller is achieved. For more details about the derivations for the guaranteed stability analysis, please refer to our previous work (Qiu et al., 2020).


Recursive attack localisation and tolerant control algorithm

At every sampling time step, the central controller collects measurement results from local units. With this information, the central controller estimates the battery SoC using the two-step set-membership estimation method. According to the calculated ellipsoids, the controller can diagnose the occurrence and locate the position of cyber-attack. Then, by solving the MPC optimisation problem, the controller will predict the future control sequence based on the attack detection result. The obtained optimal control sequence will be sent to local units as set-point signals depending on the working status of communication channels, that is, if the channel is under attack, the corresponding local unit will still implement its default control sequence stored at local before attack occurs;

if the channel works without harassment from attack, the corresponding local unit can receive and update its control sequence. The corresponding algorithm is designed as in Algorithm 1.

In simulation tests, the SME optimisation problem is solved with MATLAB YALMIP (Löfberg, 2004)  Algorithm 1 Recursive attack localisation and tolerant control algorithm.

2) Obtain the updated ellipsoid ε(x k , P k ) by solving the optimisation problem (34) and update the state estimate of the current time stepx k . If there is any attack, report ' Attack' and setx k ←x k|k−1 , P k ← P k|k−1 .

The PV and load profiles illustrated in Figure 4 are the power generation and consumption data for a typical residential household in the summertime. To simplify the data composition, it is assumed that the PV generators and the residential loads have the same evolution pattern, respectively, with the only difference being in the value magnitudes, which are proportional to one another at every time step. A DoS attack is assumed to occur at Battery 2 from time 11h to 13h, as marked in the shadow box in Figure 4.

It is also assumed that the forecasts for both the PV generation power and load power are accurate in this test and that the process disturbance and measurement noise satisfy the following bounding conditions:  and R = 0.0008 0 0 0.0008 , and the initial system state estimation error is bounded with P 0 = 0.08 0 0 0.08 . The detailed parameter values are given in Table 1.

DoS attack on sensor measurement

ξ y 2,k is initially set as 1 to represent that the measurement signal from Battery 2 is completely lost, while  1,k is set as 0 to represent that Battery 1 is free of attack. Besides, it is assumed that the control signals of the two batteries are both secure. As shown in the test results in Figure 5, at Step 21 the updated ellipsoid is inside the prediction ellipsoid. At Step 22 the two ellipsoids and their boundary sets χ p 2 and χ u 2 have no intersection, but the other group of boundary sets χ p 1 and χ u 1 intersect. According to the attack localisation criterion (35), it can be concluded that there is an attack occurring at battery 2, while battery 1 is attack-free. The same conclusion can be obtained from the plotted ellipsoids until Step 27. From

Step 27, the two ellipsoids start to have intersection again, which means both the batteries are free of attack. The obtained states of the intersection between boundary sets are illustrated in Figure 6. It can be seen that the detection and localisation results are consistent with the real status of the attack. This demonstrates that the proposed localisation method can locate the attack effectively.


Minimum detectable DoS attack

In this subsection, the minimum detectable DoS attack on the sensor of Battery 2 is tested from Step 22 to 26. From Figure 7(a-e), it can be observed that the update ellipsoid 'just touches' the prediction ellipsoid. Correspondingly, the lower bounds ξ y 2,k of the physical constraints of the attack signals are presented in the second row of Table 2, which means the detectable DoS attack on the sensor of Battery 2 must be subject to the physical constraint that ξ y 2,k ≤ ξ y 2,k ≤ 1 and the minimum detectable DoS attack is ξ y 2,k y 2,k .


Minimum locatable DoS attack

The ellipsoids under the minimum locatable DoS attacks are illustrated in Figure 8, and the corresponding lower bounds ξ y 2,k are presented in the third row of Table 2. From Figure 8(a-e), it can be observed that the minimum locatable attack deviates the update ellipsoid with the minimum value while the boundary sets of Battery 2 have no intersection.


DoS attack on control signal

The proposed detection method is tested with DoS attack on the control signal of Battery 2, while its sensor measurement is free of attack. For simplicity, the following setting is given: ξ u 1,k = 0, ξ u 2,k = 1, ξ y 1,k = 0, ξ y 2,k = 0. The DoS attack still occurs from k = 22 to k = 26. The test results are shown in Figure 9. It can be observed that the two ellipsoids have no intersection from k = 23 to k = 27 and have intersections again from k = 28. This is because the attack on the control signal at time step k can only be detected at next time step k + 1 after the sensor measurement is updated.


Cyber-attack tolerant control test

In this test, to simulate the worst-case scenario, it is assumed that cyber-attacks will affect the data transmission channels in both directions, that is, both the sensor measurement output and the control signal input are completely lost when DoS attack occurs. The test results are shown in Figure 10, where the first  picture illustrates the PV and load profiles for three consecutive days. It can be observed in the following pictures that the central controller can effectively regulate the charging/discharging power of batteries, despite the occurrence of cyber-attack at battery 2. The proposed control strategy can not only locate the attack based on the measurement output, but also overcome the attack on the control signal channel to achieve the cyber-attack tolerant control. Another benefit of the proposed control strategy is that it can smoothen the grid power as illustrated in the last picture.


Conclusion

A cyber-attack localisation method based on ellipsoidal set-membership estimation for microgrid EMS is proposed in this paper. This method can estimate the battery SoC with the existence of both cyberattacks and other process and measurement disturbances and provide attack location information for the control centre. Based on the attack localisation result, MPC controller computes an optimal control sequence for the local battery units through solving the optimisation problem. With the real-time recursive algorithm, the local units can update their default setpoint control signals continuously if they are attackfree and they can still utilise the stored default signals if their communication channels are jammed. From the simulation test results, it can be observed that the proposed control strategy can locate the attack and achieve the cyber-attack tolerant control effectively. In conclusion, the proposed localisation method can provide more detailed location information of the attack, compared with the previous SME-based cyber-attack detection method. Besides, the presented tolerant control can not only make effective use of the control inputs predicted by MPC to overcome the communication failure, but also smoothen the power drained from or fed into the external utility grid. In future research, some commonly used communication protocols for the microgrid EMS will be considered, for example, the WTOD protocol to prevent data collisions and reduce energy cost (Ju et al., 2020b) or the stochastic communication protocol to relieve communication burden (Ju et al., 2020a). In these circumstances, the cyber-attack detection and tolerant control methods will require further modifications so as to satisfy the system performance requirements. control systems, model predictive control, power electronics and energy storage management in microgrids.

Yang received the Ph.D. degree in control engineering from Huazhong University of Science and Technology, China, in 1990. He is currently an Associate Professor at Griffith University, Australia. Before joining Griffith, he was a Research Fellow at Brunel University and King's College London, UK, a Professor at Fuzhou University and East China University of Science and Technology, China, and an Associate Professor at Central Queensland University, Australia. He also held a Visiting Professor at the University of Manchester, UK, and the University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong. His current research interests include networked control systems, distributed filtering and sensing, reliable fault detection and diagnosis, distributed control and filtering, microgrids with renewable energy integration, and robot imitation learning for healthcare. He is an Associate Editor of IEEE Industrial Electronics Magazine, Frontiers in Energy Research-Smart Grids, the Journal of the Franklin Institute, and the IEEE CSS Conference Editorial Board. Yong Zhu received a Ph.D. degree in Microelectronics from the Peking University, Beijing, China, in 2005. He worked as a Research Associate in the Department of Engineering, University of Cambridge, UK, in 2006 and 2007. From 2008 to 2011, he was a Research Academic in the School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, the University of Newcastle, Australia. Currently he holds a Senior Lecturer position at the School of Engineering and Built Environment, Griffith University, Australia. His research interests include Nano/Microelectromechanical Systems (N/MEMS) analysis and design, micro-fabrication, robust control of microactuators, as well as interface circuits design for micro-sensors.
